column2: The Beregrim were the Edain of Eraidor. They gave rise to those of the Houses of Bëor and Hador, and remained in Eraidor well into the Second Age.

The Nenedian were relatives to the Edain who never crossed the Misty Mountains. Early in the Second age, they became close allies of the Longbeards. They were mostly destroyed during the War of the Elves and Sauron, but the Dwarves have carried their names ever since.
Arvandor, later known as Rhudaur, was settled in the early Second Age by a people who were relatives to the Beregrim to the west and the Nenedain to the east.
Gondorian middle men are of mixed ancestry, with both hillmen ancestors and traces of numenorean blood, though they no longer have the strength and long life of their dunedain ancestors.
column3: Les Gondoriens communs descendent de deux peuples différents qui se sont mélangés au fil du temps. Les Numénoréens ont ainsi dilués leur sang parmi les peuples originaux de la région.

column2: Arnorian middle men are of mixed ancestry, with both hillmen and Haladin ancestors and traces of numenorean blood, though they no longer have the strength and long life of their dunedain ancestors.
column3: Les Arnoriens communs descendent de deux peuples différents qui se sont mélangés au fil du temps. Les Numénoréens ont ainsi dilués leur sang parmi les peuples originaux de la région.

column2: The Forodwaith, or Helmivalmistajat, are an ancient nomadic culture of the far north, ancestors of the Hillmen of Angmar and relatives of the Lossoth.
Followers of Ingwë, they were blond and pretty and went to Aman, and stayed there.

Followers of Finwë, they went to Aman. However, events prompted many of them to head back to Middle-Earth, and as such they are the only High Elves on the map. They also have a crafting tradition rivalling that of the Dwarves.
Formed from those Teleri who reached Aman, this Elven culture is both highly Maritime and stay-at-home.

The Grey-Elf culture formed in the 3rd age from those Teleri who reached Beleriand, but missed the boat to Aman. Under the leadership of Elu Thingol and Melian, they formed a thriving civilization before the Noldor came back, and thier culture persists among many elves until the 3rd age and later.
The 'Shore-Elves', who since the First Age have been shipbuilders and sailors, under the guidance of Círdan the Shipwright. They are often considered a subset of the Sindar.

The original Wood-Elves, the center of their culture was Lindórinand, which later became Lórien. Their culture eventually shifted to Silvan, but this took quite some time. Some, like Nimrodel, stayed Nandor well into the Third Age.
The Green-Elves of Ossiriand were a Nandor offshoot who migrated into Beleriand during the First Age.
The Wood Elves of old came under the influence of Sindar culture, to the point where by the end of the 3rd age, they were all speaking Sindarin. This 'new' wood-elf culture is called Silvan.

The Sirannar are elves related to the Nandor and the Green-Elves of Ossiriand, but whose homeland lay in Southwestern Arthedain (Siragale), in Eriador. They persisted well into the second age, and provided many migrants to Lindon.
Elves whose ancestors refused to journey to Aman. Likely a primitive lot.
The 'Kul Uruk' Ice-Orcs were bred by Mogoth as guardians of the Ered Engrin. They thrive in frigid temperatures and high elevations.
This empty land is not peopled.
